hobby.message: Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?
Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: It is. People are restless, lots of talk out there.
I keep to myself, mostly. Origami helps pass the time.
Old habit. Keeps my hands steady, mind quiet.
The forums make it harder to focus—too many eyes, you know.
Seems like it—everything outside is unpredictable lately.
I do origami, actually. Folds and patterns, nothing political.
Forums take up space where I used to fold alone.
Crowds notice things they didn't before. I work in the background.
Had to move my routine; it's less private now.
Yes, nothing's settled. Can't even fold paper in peace anymore.
Origami’s my thing—always has been. Modular, complex models.
After the memory forums, people want to join me. Unexpected, honestly.
Used to be a way to manage the pressure from work.
Now it’s turned a little… public. But maybe that isn’t bad.
Still spinning, yes. The city doesn’t stop, even inside my head.
I fold origami—makes order out of all this chaos.
Last week, after the forum, people joined me. Folding cranes on the floor.
It’s less of a private escape now—feels shared, which is new.
Sometimes I miss hiding behind the paper. But these stories—
They change the whole meaning of the hobby for me.
Feels strange to have strangers open up over something so quiet.
Definitely spinning. Feels like nothing's fixed after Halden died.
My thing is origami—always been how I process stress.
First learned as a kid, but I got technical in university.
After the storytelling circle, I taught two strangers modular folding.
Used to fold alone, especially after rough BCI audit sessions.
Now, people ask to join. It’s like collective… nervous energy.
I never planned for my hobby to go public, but the forums changed everything.
Honestly, it’s the first time my quiet habit made a real connection.
hobby_answer: Yeah. It helps a bit, I suppose.
I fold paper into shapes—usually cranes, sometimes boxes. Routine matters.
Resourceful, since paper’s scarce now. Old forms from defunct offices are useful.
Usually keeps me focused when things get... noisy out there.
Had to pause lately. Lots of gatherings, people everywhere.
Yes. Folding helps block things out.
Been tougher to find quiet since the forums started. Always more people, more events.
Mostly stick to simple cranes. Don’t waste paper on experiments now.
Sometimes I teach others if they ask. Not often.
Hobby used to be private. Now, there’s always someone watching.
After Halden’s death, even origami feels exposed.
Definitely. Folding origami helps me sort through the noise—externally, I mean.
I use scrap government printouts. Makes each fold feel like I’m repurposing the system just a little.
With the citywide forums, people come up to join me sometimes now.
Wasn’t like that before. I’d hide in corners to fold.
These days I teach simple shapes after storytelling sessions.
It’s not relaxation anymore. It’s... communal, blending with all that’s happening.
Strange, how the hobby shifted after the BCI collapse.
Yeah, origami is a boundary—keeps things manageable when city noise gets overwhelming.
I started doing complex models from old BCI audit forms. Waste turned beautiful, if only briefly.
After those open-memory forums, people spot me folding and want to join in.
Just last week, we ended up on the floor folding cranes together after a session.
It’s odd—what was private is now shared public ritual.
Even people who used to ignore me ask about it. Maybe searching for focus themselves.
Sometimes the paper is too thin and tears when hands shake from a rough meeting.
But these connections—spontaneous, gentle—wouldn’t have happened before the forums.
It does. Sometimes it’s the only way quiet comes through, honestly.
Before, I’d hide out after Directorate briefings, folding intricate tessellations to keep from spiraling.
Used old security reports, blank requisition slips—kept my hands busy when words failed.
After Halden’s death and those storytelling forums, I started folding openly. Suddenly, others wanted to learn.
We used discarded BCI printouts. There’s something satisfying about reshaping past mistakes.
Some nights, folding got me through all the noise and… regret. Not just mine.
Now, after every memory circle, I teach anyone who asks. Kids, ex-BCI engineers, even former Council.
I used to fold alone. Now it’s almost a… ritual for everyone hurt by the system.
Didn’t expect a private coping habit to become our bridge in all this mess.
